SENT.plain: The authors present a case of late-onset cavernous sinus thrombosis in a 74-year-old man who had undergone transsphenoidal craniotomy for a pituitary macroadenoma 9 weeks previously
The patient developed headache, rapidly progressive ophthalmoplegia, and signs of orbital congestion
After 2 days of ineffective broad spectrum antibiotic therapy he underwent a second transsphenoidal craniotomy for abscess drainage
Intraoperative cultures grew 4+ non-hemolytic Streptococcus, 4+ Staphylococcus coagulase negative, and 4+ Haemophilus influenzae
The patient was maintained on intravenous antibiotic therapy for the following 6 weeks, resulting in a complete clinical recovery
To the authors' knowledge, this is the first report of a septic cavernous sinus thrombosis following a transsphenoidal craniotomy
